oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Vanderbilt University Waltz
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Students; Universities & colleges; Sheet music covers; Lyricists; Musicians; Musical instruments
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Cover has inset photograph of Mabel Lee McFerrin, the song's author, in upper left-hand corner beside title. Inset photograph of the Vanderbilt University Glee and Banjo and Mandolin Clubs is positioned in lower center. Top of cover reads: "Dedicated to Vanderbilt University Glee and Banjo and Mandolin Clubs." The majority of the cover has decorative borders with drawings of a tambourine, mandolin, banjo and trumpet.
Mabel McFerrin
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: McFerrin, Mabel Lee
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Kenneth D. Rose Sheet Music Collection
Tennessee State Library & Archives
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees, that may be necessary for the intended use.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Swedish melodies as sung by Madlle. Jenny Lind
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Sheet music covers; Clothing & dress; Women; Singers
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Oval lithograph with border of Jenny Lind (1820-1887), seated with hands folded, wearing formal dress and flowers in her hair. "Written and composed by A.F. Lindblad." "Rendered into English from the Swedish by J. Wrey Mould." Lithograph by Sarony & Co. Jenny Lind autograph facsimile at lower right.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Sarony & Co.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Kenneth D. Rose Sheet Music Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Jenny Lind, known as the "Swedish Nightingale," was a popular singer in Europe and America in the mid-nineteenth century. She performed in Nashville in 1851.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee State Library & Archives
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees, that may be necessary for the intended use.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The washing day: a proper new ballad for wet weather
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Sheet music covers; Fictitious characters; Laundry; Weather; Clotheslines
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Drawing of an angry-looking man in dressing gown and cap, with glasses perched on his forehead. He appears in the clouds above a clothesline holding laundry. On the ground are baskets, pails, an iron, and scrubbing brushes.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Clay, Edward Williams, 1799-1857
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Kenneth D. Rose Sheet Music Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Song lyrics lament the writer's wife's poor temperament on washing days. A good example of the genre of comic songs popular in the late nineteenth century. Author anonymous; song lyrics thought to have been written between 1817 and 1819.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee State Library & Archives
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees, that may be necessary for the intended use.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: A sailor's grave by the sea
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Sheet music covers; Dogs; Beaches; Graves; Shipwrecks
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Blue-toned print of a dog lying on a grave at the seashore with a wrecked vessel in the shallow water just offshore. Under print: "Words and Music by Paul Dresser." Cover artist unknown.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Kenneth D. Rose Sheet Music Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The composer, Paul Dresser, dedicated this song to his sister, Mary. The song tells of a dog who wouldn't leave his master's grave and was found dead there.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee State Library & Archives
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees, that may be necessary for the intended use.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: When it's night time down in Dixieland
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Sheet music covers; Log cabins; Freedmen; Musical instruments; Entertainers; African Americans
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Cover shows a nighttime scene of a group of African Americans singing, dancing, and playing the violin and banjo. Inset photograph at lower right of song performers Val Harris and Jack Manion.
Val Harris; Jack Manion
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Barbelle, 1888-1957
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Kenneth D. Rose Sheet Music Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Words and music by Irving Berlin.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee State Library & Archives
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees, that may be necessary for the intended use.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Defend your country
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Symbols; Flags
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Color lithograph of Uncle Sam pulling up his shirt sleeves and published "in the interest of National Defense." Uncle Sam stands in front of an unfurled American flag and is ready for a fight. Stamped in bottom right corner: "Strobel's Music Shop / 29 Arcade / Nashville, Tenn."
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Woodburn, Thomas
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Kenneth D. Rose Sheet Music Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: On inside cover: "This patriotic song was inspired by the famous United States Army poster, "Defend Your Country," painted by Major Tom B. Woodburn, U.S.A., noted artist, who collaborated on this song with the well known composers, John W. Bratton and; Leo Edwards."
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee State Library & Archives
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees, that may be necessary for the intended use.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Crow quadrilles
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Sheet music covers; Caricatures; African Americans; Ethnic stereotypes
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The antebellum character Jim Crow is surrounded by seven demeaning caricatures of African Americans: one wearing fancy uniform and carrying sword; hunting with rifle; fight over a woman; man on boat looking at alligator; man dressed in formal attire; man; with eyeglasses; and man with banjo trying to catch raccoon sitting on a fence. Crescent moon in sky. Written in pencil on front lower right: "35 cts_."
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Kenneth D. Rose Sheet Music Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Jim Crow was a character in a minstrel show and the term eventually came to mean "Negro."
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee State Library & Archives
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees, that may be necessary for the intended use.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The red stockings
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Sheet music covers; Baseball players
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Black and white lithograph shows baseball scene with focus on pitcher wearing the Cincinnati Red Stockings uniform and mutton chop sideburns. Circling the pitcher are portraits of nine named players in ovate frames. At head of title: "To the; Ladies of Cincinnati."
Clockwise from upper left: _____ Sweasy; Harry Wright; _____ Allison; Fred Waterman; _____ McVey; Andy Leonard; _____ Brainard; Geo. Wright; Charlie Gould.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Snyder, Black & Sturn
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Kenneth D. Rose Sheet Music Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The "Reds" toured the country in 1869, the year of this publication. The club is considered the first professional team in baseball, and the club's record was 57-0. This is the oldest known piece of baseball sheet music.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee State Library & Archives
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees, that may be necessary for the intended use.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Here's your mule
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Mules; Saddles; Sheet music covers
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Cover features full side view of saddled mule. Beyond the mule are army camp tents. "Here's Your Mule" written in arc across cover. "Comic Camp Song and Chorus by C.D. Benson."
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: German & Bro. Lith. (Louisville, Ky.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Kenneth D. Rose Sheet Music Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Heard frequently in Civil War army camps, the title came from a farmer whose mules had been commandeered by John Hunt Morgan, a Confederate cavalryman known for his daring raids.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee State Library & Archives
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees, that may be necessary for the intended use.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Casey Jones the brave engineer
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Sheet music covers; Railroad locomotives; Railroad employees; Railroad accidents
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Cover shows a drawing of locomotive number 5, with photographs of two men (presumably the songwriters) in railroad gear inserted in what appear to be engine windows. "Words by T. Lawrence Seibert, music by Eddie Newton." "The only comedy railroad song."
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Seibert, T. Lawrence
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Kenneth D. Rose Sheet Music Collection
Tennessee State Library & Archives
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees, that may be necessary for the intended use.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: I can pick de winner wid my two eyes shut
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Sheet music covers; Caricatures; African Americans; Blackface entertainers
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Cover shows a caricature drawing of an African American couple wearing formal clothing. The man is bowing and the woman is curtsying. At right is a tiered cake on a table with a sign reading "Dis cake will be given to de most graceful couple." Inset; photograph at upper left of a performer in blackface on crutches, wearing one large shoe. Song lyrics describe a cakewalk contest.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: O. K. Houck Co.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Kenneth D. Rose Sheet Music Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: At top: "Introduced with great success by Verner E. Phelps, of Brown-Harrison & Brown." Words by Verner E. Phelps. Music by P. Sweningson.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee State Library & Archives
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees, that may be necessary for the intended use.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Raw recruits
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Sheet music covers; Caricatures; African Americans; Soldiers; United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Cover depicts caricatures of five African-American soldiers, three with bayonets, one playing a drum, and one holding a sign reading "Raw Recruits, Capt. Dan Bryant." They appear hapless and comically inept. They are lined up in front of tents in camp. Below title: "or Abraham's Daughter, as sung with great applause by Bryants Minstrels of New York."
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Sarony, Major & Knapp Lith.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Kenneth D. Rose Sheet Music Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This song was written by Septimus Winner (1827-1902), a prominent nineteenth-century songwriter. He also wrote under the pseudonyms of Alice Hawthorne, Percy Guyer, Mark Mason, Apsley Street, and Paul Stenton.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee State Library & Archives
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees, that may be necessary for the intended use.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Centennial national song
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Sheet music covers; Presidents; Farmers; Eagles; Railroads; Ships; Symbols
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A small engraving of rural America with a train, factory, farmers, ships, and workers, is surrounded by a decorative frame of leaves, which lists the names of states and past presidents of the United States. Also pictured are Lady Liberty surrounded by symbols of America; George Washington; and Gen. Ulysses S. Grant. Words by M.I.W; Music by Henry Weber.
George Washington; Ulysses S. Grant
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Kenneth D. Rose Sheet Music Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The 1876 Centennial International Exposition took place in Philadelphia, Pa., to commemorate the signing of the Declaration of Independence in 1776. Publisher Jesse French was a prominent piano seller based in Nashville who also became involved in; publishing ragtime sheet music.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee State Library & Archives
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees, that may be necessary for the intended use.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The National union
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Sheet music covers; Flags; Horses; Patriotism; Eagles; Capitols
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Features a color engraving of the U.S. Capitol; two men on horseback look at the building from afar. An oval gold chain, in which each state is represented by a link, is superimposed on an arch with gray Doric columns. Above capitol: "In Union's Chain, within its Spell, Freedom, and peace and safety dwell." Includes facsimile message and signature of Henry Clay, to whom the piece is dedicated.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: T. Sinclair's Lith.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Kenneth D. Rose Sheet Music Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Song celebrates Clay's work to preserve the Union after difficulties of passing the Compromise of 1850. Words and music by Charles Collins, Jr.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee State Library & Archives
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees, that may be necessary for the intended use.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: I'm livin' in hopes of gettin' a man, a real real man
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Women; Love; Courtship; Sheet music covers
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Cover art shows a well-dressed woman inspecting a line of prospective dates with eyeglasses. There are two small photographs (blue tint) included on the cover: Lew Roberts (songwriter) and Lulu McConnell (performer known for this song).
Lew Roberts; Lulu McConnell
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Daniel C. Hirsch Co.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Kenneth D. Rose Sheet Music Collection
Tennessee State Library & Archives
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees, that may be necessary for the intended use.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Jeff in petticoats: a song for the times
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Cross dressing; Escapes; Firearms; Tents; Horses; Soldiers; Women; Sheet music covers; United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Confederate President Jeff Davis is pictured fleeing (in a crinoline dress) from an army camp, holding a dagger as a bonnet flies off his head. A soldier aims at gun at him and a woman in a dress appears to be in distress. Words by George Cooper. Music by Henry Tucker.
Jefferson Davis
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Eno, Henry C.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Kenneth D. Rose Sheet Music Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Jeff Davis fled Richmond, Virginia, in the spring of 1865 when the Confederacy fell to the Union. When he was caught in Irwinsville, Georgia, on May 19, 1865, he was rumored to be dressed in his wife's clothing in order to evade capture. He argued that in the dark he had mistakenly grabbed his wife's raglan when he heard horsemen approaching. Varina Davis, his wife, apparently threw her shawl around his shoulders as well, making it appear as if he were dressed as a woman.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee State Library & Archives
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees, that may be necessary for the intended use.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The children of the battlefield
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Sheet music covers; Children; Families; United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Lithograph from a photograph of three young children serves as the centerpiece of the cover of a Civil War-era song, dedicated by the author, James G. Clark, to J. Francis Bourns M.D. of Philadelphia, Pa.
L-r: Frank Humiston; Frederick Humiston; Alice Humiston
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: P.S. Duval & Son
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Kenneth D. Rose Sheet Music Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: After the Battle of Gettysburg, a dead soldier was found on the field with an ambrotype of his three young children. The photograph was obtained by Dr. Francis Bourns who then had the photograph reproduced so that someone might be able to identify; the children. It was eventually determined that the father of the children was the late Amos Humiston, of Portville, Cattaraugus County, New York, a Sergeant in the 154th New York Volunteers. The children's names were Frank, Frederick, and Alice.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee State Library & Archives
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees, that may be necessary for the intended use.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Keep away from the fellow who owns an automobile
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Automobiles; Automobile driving; Montgomery, Ray; Healy Sisters
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Cover depicts a car with a running board. The driver sits on the right side of the coupe and the lady to his left with scarf blowing in the breeze as the top is down. Inset photograph of Ray Montgomery and the Healey Sisters (song performers).
Ray Montgomery; Healey [i.e. Healy] Sisters
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Pfeiffer, E. H.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Kenneth D. Rose Sheet Music Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Words and music by Irving Berlin.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee State Library & Archives
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees, that may be necessary for the intended use.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Meet me at Skalowski's
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Confectioneries; Couples; Roberts, Lew
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Cover depicts a couple dressed in Edwardian finery walking from a confectionery. Both are wearing gloves and he is carrying a cane and she is holding his arm. She has on a large hat with a feather surrounding it and a feather boa around her neck. Inset; photograph of Lew Roberts (songwriter) at lower left.
Lew Roberts
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Kenneth D. Rose Sheet Music Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Maurice H. Skalowski, the proprietor of "America's Handsomest Confectionery Parlor," provided scenes from his establishment on the reverse cover to encourage patrons to visit. The establishment was located at 217 Fifth Avenue North, Nashville, Tennessee.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee State Library & Archives
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees, that may be necessary for the intended use.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The blue & the gray
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Civil wars; Military officers; Generals; Peace; Surrenders; Grant, Ulysses S. (Ulysses Simpson), 1822-1885; Lee, Robert E. (Robert Edward), 1807-1870
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Cover depicts Gen. Ulysses S. Grant and Gen. Robert E. Lee, in uniform, shaking hands, with the slogan "Let us have peace" printed above them. The remains of the battlefield are shown on the ground around them, including cannon, flags, and a drum.
Ulysses S. Grant; Robert E. Lee
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Kenneth D. Rose Sheet Music Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Song and chorus written by Miss Ida Scott Taylor. Composed by Henry M. Butler.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee State Library & Archives
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees, that may be necessary for the intended use.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The political quartet
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Flags; Political parties; Political elections
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Cover depicts portraits of four 1896 presidential candidates positioned at each corner of the page with the American flag announcing elections in which the Republican, Democrat, Prohibition and Populist parties were represented. Portraits are unlabeled.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Kenneth D. Rose Sheet Music Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Subtitle: "Dedicated to the American People. Four Songs and Chorus for Republican, Democrat, Prohibition and Populist Parties." Music by W.L. Needham. Each party's verses separately written, by J.L. Gardner (Republican), W.L. Needham (Democrat), W.L. Tandy (Prohibition), and Malda Owen (Populist). Candidates were William McKinley (Republican), William Jennings Bryan (Democrat/Populist), and Joshua Levering (Prohibition).
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee State Library & Archives
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees, that may be necessary for the intended use.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Hail! Glorious banner of our land
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Liberty; Flags; Sailing ships; Eagles; Ammunition; Symbols
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Cover depicts Lady Liberty standing boldly in a harbor with her left foot on wrapped coils of gunpowder encased around an axe. The American Eagle is shown to her right rear and tall ships can be seen in the harbor. Color.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: T. Sinclair's Lith.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Kenneth D. Rose Sheet Music Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "Respectfully inscribed to Major General George B. McClellan by Mrs. Mary Farrell Moore, Cincinnati, Ohio, July 4th, 1861." Music by Charles Warren, Cincinnati.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee State Library & Archives
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Long boy
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Soldiers; Marching; Farms; Mules; Dogs; Swine; Roosters; Arrivals & departures; Families; Farewells; World War, 1914-1918
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Comical drawing in which a soldier with rifle on his shoulder marches off to World War I down a dirt road and leaves in the background mother, father, sweetheart, a dog, and a mule sticking its head out of a barn. American flags are being waved by those; left behind, and a pig and a rooster are also visible. Subtitle on cover reads "Goodbye Ma! Goodbye Pa! Goodbye, Mule with yer old Hee-Haw!"
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Wiliams, Gaar, 1880-1935
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Kenneth D. Rose Sheet Music Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Words by William Herschell; music by Barclay Walker. Song lyrics deal with a tall, thin young man enlisting for World War I.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee State Library & Archives
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The drummer boy of Shiloh
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Battlefields; War casualties; Civil wars; Soldiers
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Cover depicts fallen drummer boy surrounded by mourning comrades and other casualties as the Battle of Shiloh rages. Cover image has only sepia tint.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Slinglandt, Jacob
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Kenneth D. Rose Sheet Music Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Song written and composed by Will S. Hays. Dedicated to Miss Annie Cannon, Louisville, Ky.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee State Library & Archives
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Come on to Nashville Tennessee
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Couples; Railroad stations; Railroad employees; Passengers; Railroad travel; Arrivals & departures
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A man and a woman carrying baggage approach a gate and a railroad employee to board a pictured train headed to Nashville, Tennessee. Cover image is done in green and white.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: [McKay?]
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Kenneth D. Rose Sheet Music Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Song lyrics describe a young man inviting his belle to meet his family in his hometown of Nashville, Tennessee. Words and music by Walter Donaldson.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee State Library & Archives
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Grant, our great commander
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Grant, Ulysses S. (Ulysses Simpson), 1822-1885; Battlefields; Campaigns & battles; Historic sites; Surrenders; Victories; Military leadership; Military officers; Generals; Sheet music covers
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A portrait of Union Army General Ulysses S. Grant appears at the center of the engraved cover, surrounded by Civil War-related line drawings entitled "Donelson," "Vicksburg," "Lee's Surrender," and "White House Wash'n."
Ulysses S. Grant
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Kenneth D. Rose Sheet Music Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Cover of a campaign song "respectfully dedicated to the Grand Army of the Republic." Music by Bernard Covert; words by Maj. J. Barton.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee State Library & Archives
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: If that's your idea of a wonderful time, take me home
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Motion pictures; Dating (Social custom); Couples; Ticket offices
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Cover lithograph shows a gentleman trying to encourage his lady friend to go with him to the 5 cent moving pictures. She stands with her back to him in an unhappy pose. The ticket booth is between them.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Frew, John
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Kenneth D. Rose Sheet Music Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "Words and music by Irving Berlin." Cover signed by Margaret Draper.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee State Library & Archives
